title: Neuromotor rehabilitation by Neurofeedback

author: Piero Paolo Battaglini, University of Trieste

segmentation: I will start it.

From the very beginning, everybody knows that in order to produce movement, it is fundamental that the brain is somehow connected to the to the to the muscle and somehow means with the spinal cord and nerves.
And if you have a disruption somewhere, there is no way to regain communication, at least by the biological point of view by the medical point of view.
So in this case is.
What can it be done?
Typically you can approach the problem with the brain computer interface.
What you do when the pathway is lesion and you try to record the original signal.
Try to understand what those neurons are saying and if you do that, you can now do something with the periphery and this.
Is the usual setup for a brain computer interface.
You have to acquire the signal.
You have to analyze it identificate what it is important.
Usually this system work with frequency of waves or a worker potential or whatever it is you which you can understand.
Then you classify what you have found in order to produce something.
You have the case of speller which is used to help people think to lock it in patient to help people to communicate.
Or you can move.
Chair wins or or whatever you want when the application is used not to produce something in the external environment, but to modulate the brain activity itself.
The procedure takes the name of neurofeedback.
An it is known that it is work.
But what happens if the lesion is at the origin of the signal?
What happens if you destroy the origin?
There is no way to use a brain computer interface, it will not.
It will not work.
What you can?
This is the case of stroke, which destroys neurons, which destroys the fibers which destroy the origin of the signal.
So what what can it be done in this case one?
Ability is to use neurofeedback and why should?
Neurofeedback work you have here.
A series of pet images in healthy and paraplegic subject.
The healthy subject has been requested to move a joystick and you see in the path which parts of the brain are activated.
Of course the sensory motor region, of course the cerebellum.
To the paraplegic patient.
It has been asked again to move the joystick.
Of course he cannot, but he makes a big effort.
In order to do it, and you see, with a huge increase, there is in the brain regions which are activated.
It means a possibly that if some region is destroyed, the surrounding one might take the role.
Make the job over the lesion at one.
Which kind of signal maybe use it.
The easiest is the EG because it is not invasive and can be done quite easily.
What does it happens when you decide to move on the left?
You have the power spectrum of a subject at rest.
Very well relaxed, you have high power in some frequencies, which means that there is some kind of synchronization.
You know what I mean?
Synchronization of neurons.
They discharge altogether when you decide to perform a movement, neurons start to work very strongly and apparently independently one from the other.
And what happens is what is known as the synchronization reduction of amplitude.
Cause neurons are no longer synchronized.
When you perform movement, and this of course happens on the sensory motor cortex.
Another information which is useful in this field is that when you imagine to perform a movement, the same brain region are activated as those which are.
Activated when you actually perform the movement.
Here you have three reconstruction of echo cortical graphical recordings during surgery.
Over patient who was requested to move the canggu.
Movement to imagine to move that angle and to drive something.
It was a cursor on the screen when thinking to move the tongue, which is actually neurofeedback.
And what you see is that almost the same regions are involved.
So placing these things all together.
And waiting for the patient.
We had these three objectives.
The first one to set up a procedure to find which brain region regions are best suited to be used for neurofeedback.
The second goal was to build a low cost and portable instrument, low-cost becauses it was already been underlined.
Money is very important in this field, so the system which we wish to develop reader to be low-cost and it'll be small.
But it will be portable.
In order to be used in the clinic, of course, but possibly even at home and then to develop a neurofeedback treatment with this instrument.
To be associated, of course, to a conventional rehabilitation procedure.
In order to speed up the recovery after stroke.
What we did we already worked with 16 subjects students, of course.

Eight of them entered experimental group, eight of them a control, one they underwent some questionary in order to know which candidate preferred, and we selected right handed subject, and also they underwent movement imagery questionnaire E in order to understand how good they were in Image Ng movement.
Then they.
Underwent EG EG was performed with 10 electrodes.
5 to the left and five to the right and now today only will tell you about the what we saw with the contralateral electrodes.
Neurofeedback was this one.
The subject was in front of a monitor where there was a hand.

The subject had to imagine the movement of the hand if this imagination of the movement exhibited the proper desynchronization, then the movie started and the movie went on as smoothly as possible with the improvement of imagination.
If the patient is stopped to imagine, hence changing the reduce the movie stop itself.
And this is the the protocol in experimental Group subject were recruited, entered the lab.
They underwent the questionnaire E and then perform at a motor imagery very simple, just at the beginning.
Then they were they had the hand, immobilize it with the device you were seen before for 24 hours.
After the more immobilization was complete.
After 24 hours they came back to the lab and again had.
A taste of a session of motor imagery.
After that they had the neurofeedback, 20 minutes or narrow feedback and then imagination again.
We also had a control group in the control group.
Everything was the same, but.
Subject did not perform neurofeedback because we wanted to know the effect of neurofeedback.
They simply were in front of the monitor and had took the count.
The movements of the hand which were performed by the computer itself.
What you see here are they are power Spectra from the five electrodes you see there in colors.
You see the amount of the power of the signal.
Red means you see on the high power blue means low power.
So blue means this synchronization.
Red means synchronization.
What you see this is the situation just at the start of the experiment before doing everything.
The subject is underwent no experience.
He was asked to imagine and what you see is a huge amount of desynchronization.
Which is correct because it is the same as where actually performing the movement.
In the plot, the Zero line is when the.
The hand appeared on the monitor, so the subject was requested to start to imagine and then after, let's say, 500 millisecond.
There is the change in the in the objectivity lower in the plot you have the frequency, which are approximated operators and higher you have the better lips after.
After they immobilization after 24 hours, subject were asked again to perform the same imagination, and here you see the data.
What you see is much less desynchronization, and some synchronization appears.
It is as if the subject loss tour reduced the cap.
The capability to properly imagine the movement.
The sensory motor region was the AFA.
Rented last aperance because it was blocked and possibly was DF warranted because it could not move and this reduce it.
The capability of these neurons to properly desynchronize.
Which is the effect of neurofeedback?
So I think this is after the immobilization.
Here.
You have the same plot after immobilization.
Now there is the neurofeedback and what you see is that.
The synchronization reappears.
You have any increase of desynchronization, read almost disappears, so the fattens come back to the previous one to the normal one.
Which are the results?
We were able to completely set up the new hardware, which is cheap.
We have we found an electrode cap with 19 electrons for let's say 500 euros EG amplifier 16 channels for about 1200 euros.
We wrote all the needed software and also the TV, the video movie Everything is ready and working.
So which are the conclusions?
Immobilization of the hand induces rapid effects, so it might be a good model to study in healthy subject.
The effect of illusion and neurofeedback reverts the effect of hand immobilization.
It means that Neurofeedback's actually work on the connectivity at the level of the cerebral cortex.
Moreover, the first prototype of the hardware is already working in Isola.

A second one has been ordered interested, by the way, all this job was done with another equipment outside the memory net protocol, which was used to validate this one, and we already ordered and the third one is going to be ordered in yes, solo operators are under training.
There are very good in Isola they already came once those of years or they already came us came to us in three Esther.
We already saw for patient in Isola and as we discussed it yesterday.
Unfortunately none of them actually entered the protocol because they performed very one was very good almost Lt and the other four were terrible.
They absolutely unable to attend to what we was doing.
Almost very difficult also for them to see the monitor.
But we learned yesterday that maybe we will.
Test them again because they are improving and what I've seen you.
What I've shown you is already presented works.
We were invited to present this data to work to a meeting of the neurological Society in Slovenia and the topic was a new insight into stroke and we also published the small paper who is interested.
We can ask and we will give it to them.
And this is to say who really worked your arm.
Alaska is a PhD student in our lab and now she's in charge of the group of Isola and Mark.
Lucy is a student of ours, is doing his thesis on this job and he gave a fundamental contribution to the developing of the experiment.
And Alexander Miladinovic is a PhD student.
Also him and he was responsible of assembling all the hard work.
And writing writing this software so this is.
All this story I have to tell you today.
